Award.AwardTitle: Surface-Based Inversions over Antarctica from Concordiasi Driftsonde Data: Characteristics and Comparisons with ERA-Interim and Satellite Data
Award.AbstractNarration:
Surface based inversions (SBI), situations where atmospheric temperatures increase with height above a surface, are common in Antarctica. SBI play an important role in high latitude climate, influencing the vertical mixing of energy, moisture and chemical constituents and also climate feed back and sensitivity through changes in albedo for surfaces such as sea-ice. SBI occurrence, persistence and depth over the continental Antarctic is poorly known because so few vertical measurements, elsewhere obtained from routine sonde programs, are made there.

During the CONCORDIASI (2010) campaign some 650 high quality (frequency, time) and vertical resolution NCAR driftsondes were released from within the polar vortex above the continent and surrounding ocean. This resulted in a unique data set which will be investigated for what it reveals of SBI properties over the continent. As well as having this unique dropsonde validation data set, satellite products (from the Advanced InfraRed Sounder - AIRS; and the Infrared Atmospheric Sounding Interferometer - IASI) will be combined with ERA-Interim reanalysis data products, to determine SBI depth and intensity. If the satellite and reanalysis operational products faithfully reflect observed SBI variability, the extrapolation of SBI to time periods beyond the CONCORDIASI observations will be made. In this way it is hoped that underobserved Antarctic boundary layer properties may further be revealed.

International collaboration on the project will be coordinated with colleagues at Nanjing University.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Surface based temperature inversions (SBI) occur frequently over Antarctica and play an important role in climate and weather. Inversions restrict vertical air motion and mixing, and SBIs can confine properties such as heat, moisture, and aerosols to thin layers near the surface. In this research we examined Antarctic SBIs using measurements from dropsondes, the ERA-Interim Atmospheric Reanalysis Model (ERA-Interim), and retrievals from two state-of-the-art satellite-borne infrared sounding instruments. The dropsondes provide very accurate, high-resolution direct temperature profiles. The ERA-Interim is a global atmospheric reanalysis based on a large number of in-situ and remotely sensed observations, including both surface-based and satellite measurements. The two satellite instruments were the Advanced Infrared Sounder (AIRS) and the Infrared Atmospheric Sounding Interferometer (IASI). These use complex retrieval algorithms to provide temperature profiles from atmospheric emission spectra.


The dropsonde dataset was collected during the CONCORDIASI field experiment. Detailed, high-resolution data are rare in Antarctica, and this presents a challenge for the ERA-Interim over this part of the globe since it relies on observations. The satellite sounders and algorithms are also challenged by Antarctic conditions, both because of the unusually cold surface and strong vertical temperature gradients.


Results of this research are based on a SBI detection algorithm developed as part of this work and applied to the temperature profiles. Besides the SBI properties, we evaluated the surface air temperature values from each dataset because they are critical to the SBI calculation.


Surface air temperature from all of AIRS, IASI, and ERA-Interim were found to be significantly warmer than the dropsonde measurement over the high plateau of the Antarctic interior. This was not true for surfaces closer to sea level, where the IASI temperature was colder than the dropsonde.


SBIs are characterized by their depth and intensity. We evaluated these properties, as well as their frequency of occurrence based on the SBI detection algorithm. It was found that SBIs are more prevalent, deeper, and more intense over the continent than over sea ice, especially at higher surface elevations. We found that our SBI algorithm, when applied to AIRS, IASI, and ERA-Interim, has a high probability of detection of SBIs but in many cases also severely overestimated their depth and underestimated their intensity. The difference in depth is primarily due to cases where a shallow inversion layer is present and observed by the high-resolution dropsonde, but is too shallow to be resolved by the satellites or reanalysis product. The difference in intensity is primarily due to the differences already identified in the surface air temperature measurement.


The AIRS and IASI datasets are global and cover the full depth of the atmosphere. The near-surface Antarctic environment provides special and unique challenges to their temperature profiles. This work points directly to two areas - more accurate surface temperature and better retrieval resolution - where improved performance would benefit our ability to observe the important near-surface atmosphere over data-sparse Antarctica. The ERA-Interim reanalysis makes use of satellite retrievals. In the data-sparse Antarctic, improvements in satellite retrievals have the potential to also improve the ERA-interim dataset.
